>>179024840
David Foster Wallace once wrote a piece about David Lynch. In the piece, he coined a new term: "Lynchian". Wallace described a Lynchian tone as "the unbelievably grotesque existing in a kind of union with the unbelievably banal."

He described a husband beating his 1950s housewife to death because she bought the wrong brand of peanut butter. "I told you to buy the JIF," he'd say as he's clobbering her to death. This, he said, would qualify as almost perfectly Lynchian.

I think "I Am Jazz" enters into Lynchian territory. The .webm above shows a simple domestic scene. The women look like average suburban moms. They're relaxing on the couch. One imagines they might be discussing casserole recipes when we cut to them. But it slowly dawns on us that in the living room, with placid expressions on their faces, they're talking about the woman's transvestite son's genitals.

Despite the obvious subtext and the producers' hope to normalize this horror, the average person is totally disgusted. Nevertheless, the viewer is fascinated. We're drawn further into this. The sheer naked horror of what they're saying, the blasé quality with which they're saying it, it creates this brutal paradox that almost rapes the viewer's basic sense of what is decent.

I'm on the same page. It does work to elevate people, but at what cost? I was rewatching the ending scene on youtube the other day and it said the last shot of the father was supposed to show the father had lost his son, and his son had become a monster. And Fletcher finally being proven right in his philosophy.

Not what I saw at all, but there's many different ways to look at it.

For those who give a shit: For me, personally, I had a surrogate father in my cousin. Whenever I started to get my head into the clouds, he would popquiz me in a rapid fire fashion:
>What did you do?
>What did you say?
>Where you feeling good?
And then he would pick apart the inconsistencies in what I did
>Just a second ago you said you felt this, but now you say you're feeling so
>Do you even remember the first question I asked you? You did? What was your answer?
Rapidfire

I'd get humbled each time. And each time I made a mess, I had to clean up for myself.
>If you're not going to clean up your own shit, how will you ever learn?

Sometimes he would ignore me for an entire day, until I came to the realization that there was nobody there for me and I was going to have to do it by myself. And when I really couldn't do it by myself, at the end of the day he went end took care of it for me, hoping I had learned my lesson.

Greatest tutor and surrogate father I ever had. I also learned that just ignoring people when they're doing something wrong can be a very powerful tool. Just ignore their existence, until they come around. Of course, you have to know what material you're working with, I wasn't one of those kids that would set the house on fire if you ignored them. It's not a foolproof method kek.

I get that this is a limitation of the director and writer not really knowing their subject that well, and *generally* they know enough to BS their way past a layperson audience. but like.. do some research, man. talk to some music students. go visit a school like juilliard and see what people are listening to. give it that little bit of extra verisimilitude and depth. research and knowing your subject is always that extra 10% that separates good writers and directors from great, for me.

posts.com:
Avatar: The Way Of Water has made more money in India than Endgame to become the highest-grossing foreign movie of all time in India. We Indian Hindus love Cameron's Avatar franchise even more than Marvel capeshit (inb4 poo memes/sir memes/do not redeem memes). The inspiration for Avatar was blue-skinned Hindu gods (like Vishnu and Shiva) according to Cameron himself. Also, the word 'avatar' itself means 'divine incarnation' in the ancient Sanskrit language of India. An 'avatar' is a Hindu concept that refers to the descent of a divine being from the realm of spirit to the realm of matter where we all dwell. When Avatar 1 was released, James Cameron during one of his speeches in New Delhi mentioned "I just have loved everything, the mythology, the entire Hindu pantheon, seems so rich and vivid." He continued and said, "I didn't want to reference the Hindu religion so closely, but the subconscious association was interesting, and I hope I haven't offended anyone in doing so."
Furthermore, when Cameron was asked what exactly the word 'avatar' means, he said “It's an incarnation of one of the Hindu gods taking a flesh form. In this film what that means is that the human technology in the future is capable of injecting a human's intelligence into a remotely located body, a biological body.” (source: https://www.jagrantv.com/en-show/avatar-the-way-of-water-is-the-story-related-to-matsya-avatar-cameron-spiritual-connection-with-india-rc1037160)

Also, that liquid in Avatar: The Way Of Water which stops aging is called 'amrita' and 'amrita' is a Sanskrit word meaning 'immortality'. In Hindu mythology, amrita is the nectar of the gods and the reason why the gods are immortal (or at least have very long lives by human standards).

"I just like blue. It’s a good color. Plus, there’s a connection to the Hindu deities, which I like conceptually." - James Cameron (source: https://nicolastang.org/2010/02/03/avatar/)

I've been thinking something about the comparisons Avatar makes to how Earth used to be and Pandora, how people point out it's completely different, and how so many of the animals and Na'vi are just "metaphors" for Earth animals and Humans. And then it finally hit me as someone blabbed about the floating mountains being unrealistic.

Pandora is meant to be Earth before we lost our sense of wonder and got bored with it. Before awe-inspiring sights became mundane and dull to us. All exaggerated to recapture and rejuvenate those feelings. The point isn't to have the most accurate and scientific worldbuilding, except where that assists fascination with life itself. It's not that Earth was ever literally just like Pandora in the old days, it's that it used to be just like it for us.

>>179023582
>Pandora is meant to be Earth before we lost our sense of wonder and got bored with it. Before awe-inspiring sights became mundane and dull to us. All exaggerated to recapture and rejuvenate those feelings. The point isn't to have the most accurate and scientific worldbuilding, except where that assists fascination with life itself. It's not that Earth was ever literally just like Pandora in the old days, it's that it used to be just like it for us.
That's an excellent point. It reminds me of what Mel Gibson says about Braveheart and The Patriot. The history itself in those films may be stinky poopy doodoo, but the emotional impact is true to life. You don't elicit a period accurate emotional response from a 20th century Anglophone without tweaking the story here and there. Just the same, you don't evoke the same sense of wonder about the world in the 21st century just by showing Attenborough documentaries. It takes more. People aren't awestruck by the things they used to be. Our senses have been dulled by a constant stream of oversaturated MciPhone® commercials.

As a ruralite myself, I often take the nature around me for granted, but every once in awhile I'll walk out my front door and just soak it all in and appreciate my home. It's the same with the night sky. Light polluted urbanites don't know what they're missing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I watched it bros! For the first time.
Oh my fucking god.
First of all, this movie is an experience. While watching i felt that this is just one of a kind, one in a decade experience.
Second, Cameron proves once again that he is very thoughful and talented storyteller, and perfectly knows how to play on the strings of the human soul.
Third, finally some fucking classic blockbuster. I dont want to insult Nolan or Denis, or whoever else but their action movies lacking the classic Hollywood blockbuster touch.
And its everywhere in this movie and fuck i missed it. That gunplay, feeling of the kinetic force in the punches and shots, that marine bravado, that simple yet right nods at romance between two characters - oh this is so fucking classic 80-90s kino.
Fuck i love it!
Fourth, the movie is so fucking fair and honest. Going back to home i thought how poor Neytiri is. She loose again and again and again. But then i think 'Shit, this i tough, butthats such a real depiction of events if it happened in reality'. And Cameron DOESNT try to fake it out, he is fucking real, and thats what i miss in the modern movies, especially capeshit.
Fifth, judging by /tv/ i expected Spider to be a little shit, but he turned out to be great sympathetic character.
Also his chemistry with Kiri is WHEW! I hope for some steamy romance in Avatar 3 between them. They are spreading sexual fluids around in every shared scene.
Also Kiri is hot as fuck. Holy fuck Sigourney is great at acting as a young girl.
I also see all the plot built up for the next movie with Jake mistaking his son for Neteyam, son feeling guilt, Spider not telling anyone he saved Quatrich, Quatrich potential redemption, Kiri obvious connection to the planet etc.
And how great Cameron lead audience on spiritual path. You feel the sense of wonder no other movie in the last decade gave. You feel so emotional. After the movie i came home and firstly hug my parents.
Daym, that movie is good!

>>179021910
It's not so much the nerds generally as the aging video game professionals, particularly the people making video games. They despise what they do and the audience for it. They literally want it to be something else and they really started to believe they could become the next Holllywood and that high art an respectability was right around the corner. However there are two things that will forever prevent video games from being more than games:

>player agency vs. authorial agency
You will never be able to solve this. It will be a constant tug of war with the player-viewer bouncing from one type of media to another, breaking immersion and suspension of disbelief one way or another.

>the founder effect
Movies stem from theater and are a fundamental and ancient human form of expression. Video games stem from carnies ripping off rubes on the carnival midway.

The only *slight* chance to ennoble gaming is for some company or individual to come from outside of gaming and uplift the entire thing by using video game technologies as an outsider. But even then they aren't going to look like movies. The last company that had a shot at this was Apple but they blew their wad with their shitty Arcade. It's also interesting that they wanted to get into movies and TV content at the same time. But that's what it will take: someone with a completely different approach and attitude coming in. Traditional video game studios dabbling in "story games" is just gay and pointless fart huffing by 50 year old game devs tired of making bing bing wahoos.

>>179022479
I haven't played Uncharted but the main thing I see there is that the setpiece doesn't really add much to the gameplay. Your screen shakes a bit but quickly, and especially when it really starts shaking, the enemies are too dazed to actually pose a threat and you just do an easy jump before you're back in a cutscene. I don't really mind though if a game with fun gameplay has some cutscenes and cool setpieces sprinkled in. The problem I have is when people praise the story in those games that utterly fail to take advantage of the medium to convey it. At the risk of sounding like a whiny faggot, I think people touting games like TLOU as proof video games are art or the showrunner saying it's hands down the best story in video games is genuinely harmful to the medium. I think video games are capable of giving experiences and telling stories that other mediums really can't yet people are limiting them to aping movies and TV.

>>179023466
Exactly. I don't think it's a problem if you're not focusing on the story. DMC is a good example where the story never pretends to be more than some campy action anime but it's charming enough and genuinely adds to the game while not forgetting that it's not the ultimate purpose of it. On the other hand, I stopped playing RDR2 maybe a couple hours in at most because it just felt like a poorly-paced movie where instead of having a cut to the next scene I actually had to walk over there.

“I am sending Qyburn with you, to look after you on the way to King’s Landing,” Roose Bolton said on the morn of their departure. “He has a fond hope that your father will force the Citadel to give him back his chain, in gratitude.”
“We all have fond hopes. If he grows me back a hand, my father will make him Grand Maester.”
Steelshanks Walton commanded Jaime’s escort; blunt, brusque, brutal, at heart a simple soldier. Jaime had served with his sort all his life. Men like Walton would kill at their lord’s command, rape when their blood was up after battle, and plunder wherever they could, but once the war was done they would go back to their homes, trade their spears for hoes, wed their neighbors’ daughters, and raise a pack of squalling children. Such men obeyed without question, but the deep malignant cruelty of the Brave Companions was not a part of their nature.
Both parties left Harrenhal the same morning, beneath a cold grey sky that promised rain. Ser Aenys Frey had marched three days before, striking northeast for the kingsroad. Bolton meant to follow him. “The Trident is in flood,” he told Jaime. “Even at the ruby ford, the crossing will be difficult. You will give my warm regards to your father?”
“So long as you give mine to Robb Stark.”
“That I shall.”
Some Brave Companions had gathered in the yard to watch them leave. Jaime trotted over to where they stood. “Zollo. How kind of you to see me off. Pyg. Timeon. Will you miss me? No last jest to share, Shagwell? To lighten my way down the road? And Rorge, did you come to kiss me goodbye?”

“The honor’s mine, my lord.” Ser Balon sounded wary.
“There is only one question I would put to you. You served us loyally, it’s true . . . but Varys tells me that your brother rode with Renly and then Stannis, whilst your lord father chose not to call his banners at all and remained behind the walls of Stonehelm all through the fighting.”
“My father is an old man, my lord. Well past forty. His fighting days are done.”
“And your brother?”
“Donnel was wounded in the battle and yielded to Ser Elwood Harte. He was ransomed afterward and pledged his fealty to King Joffrey, as did many other captives.”
“So he did,” said Jaime. “Even so . . . Renly, Stannis, Joffrey, Tommen . . . how did he come to omit Balon Greyjoy and Robb Stark? He might have been the first knight in the realm to swear fealty to all six kings.”
Ser Balon’s unease was plain. “Donnel erred, but he is Tommen’s man now. You have my word.”
“It’s not Ser Donnel the Constant who concerns me. It’s you.” Jaime leaned forward. “What will you do if brave Ser Donnel gives his sword to yet another usurper, and one day comes storming into the throne room? And there you stand all in white, between your king and your blood. What will you do?”
“I . . . my lord, that will never happen.”
“It happened to me,” Jaime said.
Swann wiped his brow with the sleeve of his white tunic.
“You have no answer?”
“My lord.” Ser Balon drew himself up. “On my sword, on my honor, on my father’s name, I swear . . . I shall not do as you did.”
Jaime laughed. “Good. Return to your duties . . . and tell Ser Donnel to add a weathervane to his shield.”

“How does a King’s Landing lad end up with a free company?” Tyrion asked him.
The lad gave him a wary squint. “Who told you I was from King’s Landing?”
“No one.” Every word out of your mouth reeks of Flea Bottom. “Your wits gave you away. There’s no one clever as a Kingslander, they say.”
That seemed to startle him. “Who says that?”
“Everyone.” Me. “Since when?”
Since I just made it up. “For ages,” he lied. “My father was wont to say it. Did you know Lord Tywin, Kem?”
“The Hand. Once I saw him riding up the hill. His men had red cloaks and little lions on their helms. I liked those helms.” His mouth tightened. “I never liked the Hand, though. He sacked the city. And then he smashed us on the Blackwater.”
“You were there?”
“With Stannis. Lord Tywin come up with Renly’s ghost and took us in the flank. I dropped my spear and ran, but at the ships this bloody knight said, ‘Where’s your spear, boy? We got no room for cravens,’ and they buggered off and left me, and thousands more besides. Later I heard how your father was sending them as fought with Stannis to the Wall, so I made my way across the narrow sea and joined up with the Second Sons.”
“Do you miss King’s Landing?”
“Some. I miss this boy, he … he was a friend of mine. And my brother, Kennet, but he died on the bridge of ships.”
“Too many good men died that day.” Tyrion’s scar was itching fiercely. He picked at it with a fingernail.
“I miss the food too,” Kem said wistfully. “Your mother’s cooking?”
“Rats wouldn’t eat my mother’s cooking. There was this pot shop, though. No one ever made a bowl o’ brown like them. So thick you could stand your spoon up in the bowl, with chunks of this and that. You ever have yourself a bowl o’ brown, Halfman?”
“A time or two. Singer’s stew, I call it.”
“Why’s that?”
“It tastes so good it makes me want to sing.”
Kem liked that. “Singer’s stew. I’ll ask for that next time I get back to Flea Bottom. What do you miss, Halfman?”

>>179014439
she had braces in the film and in the digital upgrade, she does not. Nothing more to it than that. But they change all kinds of things in shows.

X-Files is a good example. In S1 they introduce "Cancer Man". by S1E4 the tobacco companies were giving Fox so much shit they forced them to change it to "Cigarette-smoking Man" and that's what he was every after. It was in the news at the time and everyone knew about it. In the DVD and later collections, the term "Cancer Man", which is only spoken by Mulder, is completely replaced from the beginning.

Another even cringier one is from M*A*S*H and it is the stupidest thing you could imagine. It's the episode where Col Potter's horse gets colic and BJ and Hawkeye are debating who is gonna climb up the water tower and who is gonna be on the business end of the hose to clean out the horse.

BJ says he is afraid of heights so Hawkeye shows him the other end of the hose and saysm "would you rather have this end?" And BJ starts scampering up the water tower ladder, exclaiming, "My feet are like wings, Sahib!" Someone found that objectionable when they were putting the series on DVD, so they deleted the line entirely and just showed him scrambling up the water tower.

There are tons of examples of this crap. It isn't Mandela effect, it is something that was really done with old films and tv series, and the people who watched it at the time are fully aware of it.

All in the Family was ground zero for editing out entire lines. Even old time shows like I Love Lucy and Ozzie and Harriet were victims.

posts.com: Fruit of the Loom one is funny for me because I was born in 84 and when I learned what cornucopias were I discovered this supposed "mandella effect." I was eating bugles and my mom explained to me they were like little cournicopias and I was like what's that etc. She explained what it was and I said "oh like the fruit of the loom logo." She started laughing and said I must have been confused because there was no cournicopia on the logo. When we got home I ran to the bedroom to prove it and quickly saw there was in fact no cournicopia. For 2 days I thought I was in a different dimension or a dream or something until I was in the grocery store and saw the fruit of the loom logo with the cournicopia, except it was for some other company selling something entirely different. I got real honest with myself and thought about whether or not I ever actually thoroughly inspected the logo and obviously the answer is no. Also the silhouette of the logo looks like a cournicopia is behind the image when it starts to fade on shirts. Again I was born in 84 so this was before most people claiming mandella effect were even born. Confabulations are funny. There's a lot of paranoia hills to die on, please don't die on this one anons.

>>179022269
To add to this:
Member how every movie started to sound the same because everyone started using Hans Zimmer temp tracks?
Even Hans Zimmer ended up recycling his own old work, because the editor had locked the movie to the temp track, not to the action on screen (which a new score could be composed for).

I bet the same thing has happened with feature-length collaged-together pre-visualizations. They lock into that Shark Boy sequence, and that other bit from Tron: Legacy, and the game footage inserted from HALO.

Basically what AI does, but with less original "spinning-into-something-new" creative accidents. Because everyone's just there to collect a pay check, keep their resume current and keep the bosses/agents/managers off their back.

I actually enjoy the MCU and the big mistake they've been doing is maintaining phase 3-esque film structure for every single movie. It doesn't matter if it's at the very beginning of setting something up or what else but every new MCU movie has to be a big new thing. Shang-Chi starts off grounded with a couple of fights between dudes and then ends in a supernatural war killing a generational demon. Doctor Strange has him battling Wanda across the multiverse as she kills some of the most notable characters in Marvel. Black Panther 2 is another war. Eternals is whatever it was but also something meant to be big and epic.

You can't make every movie try to be some sort of grand reveal of the next big conflict, it's just boring and uninteresting. What people loved about the first Ant-Man, the creativity and fun in being small in a regular world, is completely gone.

>>179010130
That is the actual reason although the way it's stated makes it sound like something stupid that would never happen. In reality men had button up clothing long before it was considered appropriate for women, the buttons being on the right and the holes on the left just.. became a standard over time. When fashion labels started making button up clothing for women they reversed it, using the logic that it would be more familiar for women who button up their husband's shirts. I don't think it would have helped their muscle memory at all in truth, but it was a way of differentiating button up clothes for women instead of having old hags screeching at them for wearing men's clothes.

Sort of right but mostly fucking retarded. It wasn't slaves, it was assistants of the upperclasses, as the lower classes just wore single piece tunics and sweaters, they couldn't afford buttoned garments. Women's buttoned and eventually zippered garments were left handed because they were expected to be affixed by a helper whereas men's wear was done up by the man himself. The only real exceptions were high high nobility like kings and the highest ranking members of the clergy, or knights when they got fully armored.

Georgetown University professor of English and Film and Media studies Caetlin Benson-Allott argues that Free Solo infringes upon expectations of viewers when Alex Honnold was frequently and unexpectedly at risk to die: “I could no longer trust Vasarhelyi and Chin to deliver the safe spectatorial experience I’d expected, once they’d acknowledged that they were equally committed to filming their subject’s death."

Benson-Allott acknowledges his implied death as a mechanism to achieve certain emotional effects, but remarks on its minimal focus on women. Director Elizabeth Chai Vaserhelyi and girlfriend Sanni McCandless, for instance, are reduced to supporting roles, according to Benson-Allott, while Jimmy Chin is highlighted and depicted as “Free Solo's sole author."

Furthermore, Alex Honnold’s depiction ties into gendered stereotypes, argues Benson-Allott: “Not all extreme athletes are men, yet the self-destructive masculinity of these athletes is also imposed on their spectators." These gender-stereotypes are reinforced, contends Benson-Allott, when Honnold criticizes his girlfriend Sanni McCandless for “wanting to be ‘happy and cozy’ rather than pursuing a life-threatening goal."

there are a few reasons why I personally believe in the possibility of extraterrestrial visitation in the distant past.

One reason is that there is evidence of unexplained technological advancements in ancient cultures. For example, the ancient Egyptians and Mayans had access to technologies and building techniques that were far ahead of their time. It is possible that these civilizations received assistance or influence from extraterrestrial beings.

Another reason is that there are ancient texts and artwork that some people believe depict extraterrestrial beings. For example, there are cave paintings and hieroglyphics that contain images of beings or objects that do not look like anything found on Earth.

Finally, there have been numerous alleged sightings of unexplained objects in the sky throughout history. While it is possible that some of these sightings could be explained by natural phenomena or human error, it is also possible that some of them could be evidence of ancient alien visitation.

Overall, while the belief in ancient aliens is a controversial and unproven theory, I believe that there is enough evidence to support the idea that extraterrestrial beings may have visited Earth in the distant past.

It's the world's second-largest and second-most populous continent, after Asia in both cases. Africa's population is the youngest amongst all the continents; the median age in 2012 was 19.7, when the worldwide median age was 30.4. Despite a wide range of natural resources, Africa is the least wealthy continent per capita and second-least wealthy by total wealth, behind Oceania.

>>179021531
David Foster Wallace once wrote a piece about David Lynch. In the piece, he coined a new term: "Lynchian". Wallace described a Lynchian tone as "the unbelievably grotesque existing in a kind of union with the unbelievably banal."

He described a husband beating his 1950s housewife to death because she bought the wrong brand of peanut butter. "I told you to buy the JIF," he'd say as he's clobbering her to death. This, he said, would qualify as almost perfectly Lynchian.

I think this photo enters into Lynchian territory. The image above shows a simple domestic scene. It appears to be a young mother simply buying a car. She's posing for an advertisement while holding her young daughter. But as you notice more details it slowly dawns on you that this is the absolute state of America. The Dodge Neon with body corrosion and spare tire. The coalburner covered in tattoos. The 52% toddler. The socks-with-sandals. The Mexican flags. The mask.

Despite the obvious subtext and the salesman's hope to normalize this horror, the average person is totally disgusted. Nevertheless, the viewer is fascinated. We're drawn further into this. The sheer naked horror of what they're portraying, the blase quality with which they're portraying it, it creates this brutal paradox that almost rapes the viewer's basic sense of what is decent.

>>179019013
He doesn't hate whites. He just sees the oddities amongst white people, that white people don't see in themselves.
Take the movie get out for example. It's actually based on a book.(or at least that's my theory) The book is set in the old American south. One of the characters is a black live in maid. Or what is known as a "mammy". And this mammy character does voodoo, and can see ghosts, and she's the total magical negro stereotype. The climax of the book, is when the mammy tells the little white girl "if something happens to me, then eat my eyes". And the little 12 year old girl is terrified by the notion. She *loves* the mammy character and doesn't want to think about her dying, or having to eat her eyes.

Well of course, a few chapters later, the mammy dies mysteriously off screen to the ghosts. And the little girl literally eats her eyes. Which then gives her the ability to see ghosts too, and become the hero of the story, fighting back against the ghosts and saving the white family. I think Jordan Peele was inspired by this book, and that's why the core of all the black guy's problems, comes from the white photographer wanting his eyes.

There are a lot more parallels between the book and Get Out that I'm not mentioning. I just want to get the main point across. That the book, despite sounding rather liberal for an old southern white author, still relies on the death of a magical voodoo mammy to prop up the white family. And many white people don't see any problem with this. They're like "what's the big deal?" It takes someone like Jordan Peele to re-contextualize the story to shed light on it. It's not hate, it's deconstruction.
